elements.title: Executive Leadership Team

data.value: Executive Leadership Team

This table presents the executive leadership team of WEIS MARKETS, INC., including the names, ages, and current positions of 8 senior executives with ages ranging from 50 to 67 years. The average age of the team is approximately 56.

Robert G. Gleeson: Joined October 2018; promoted to Vice President of Fresh Merchandising in July 2019 and to Senior Vice President of Merchandising and Marketing in March 2021. David W. Gose II: Joined May 2014 as Senior Vice President of Operations, previously held a senior role at Walmart Ohio. Harold G. Graber: Joined October 1989; served as Vice President for Real Estate since 1996, promoted to Senior Vice President of Real Estate and Development in February 2010, and elected Secretary in February 2014. Michael T. Lockard: Joined January 2021 as Senior Vice President and assumed the roles of Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer in March 2021; formerly with K-VA-T Food Stores, Inc. James E. Marcil: Joined September 2002 as Vice President of Human Resources and promoted to Senior Vice President of Human Resources in February 2010. Kurt A. Schertle: Joined March 2009, experienced multiple promotions including Executive Vice President of Sales and Merchandising and eventually became Chief Operating Officer in March 2014. Jonathan H. Weis: Serves as Chairman of the Board, President and Chief Executive Officer. Richard G. Zeh Jr.: Holds the position of Senior Vice President and Chief Information Officer.

elements.title: WEIS MARKETS, INC. - Executive Officers Information and Leadership Changes

data.value: Employed since 1989. Served as Vice President of Property Management and Development (1996 to April 2002), then appointed Vice President and Secretary (April 2002). In January 2004, appointed as Vice Chairman and Secretary. Became interim President and Chief Executive Officer in September 2013, appointed as President and Chief Executive Officer in February 2014, and elected Chairman of the Board in April 2015.

Joined the Company in September 2016 as Chief Information Officer and was promoted to Senior Vice President, Chief Information Officer in February 2021. Prior to joining the Company, served as Chief Financial Officer of Mazzone Management Group and held senior positions in finance and information technology in the food retail and service industries.
The Company’s stock is traded on the NYSE under ticker symbol WMK. As of March 1, 2023, there were approximately 13,868 shareholders.

elements.title: Incorporation of Financial Reporting Policies

data.value: The Company believes that, based on current conditions, materially different reported results are not likely to result from long-lived asset impairments.
The Company is self-insured for a majority of its claims and has specific liability thresholds for workers’ compensation.
The Company recognizes deferred tax assets and liabilities based on existing asset and liability differences and associated tax bases.
Earnings per share are based on the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding.
Revenue from product sales is recognized at the point of sale, with discounts recognized as a reduction in sales.
Cost of sales includes direct product costs, advertising, and distribution center costs.

elements.title: WEIS MARKETS, INC. PART III - Executive Compensation & Related Disclosures

data.value: Part I of Form 10-K incorporates by reference several sections of the 2023 definitive proxy statement, including information about Executive Officers, Election of Directors, Board Committees, Audit Committee, Corporate Governance, Compensation Tables and Stock Ownership. Specifically, Item 11 covers Executive Compensation by referencing 'Board Committees and Meeting Attendance, Compensation Committee,' 'Executive Compensation, Compensation Discussion and Analysis,' 'Compensation Committee Report,' 'Compensation Tables,' and related information.

Other items in Part III include disclosures on Directors, Security Ownership, Related Transactions, Director Independence, and Auditing Fees, all incorporated by reference from the definitive proxy statement.

The document also includes a Financial Statements Table of Contents listing Consolidated Balance Sheets, Income Statements, Comprehensive Income, Shareholders' Equity, Cash Flows, Notes to Financial Statements, and the Report of the Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm (with PCAOB ID: 49).
Schedule II - Valuation and Qualifying Accounts is referenced on page 46, with other schedules omitted as applicable per SEC accounting regulations.

data.value: WEIS MARKETS, INC.
Weis 2 Go Online and Home Delivery
Offered in 188 locations in 2022 (up 2 since end of 2021). Enables online ordering with drive-thru pickup.
Started in third quarter 2018; available in 195 locations via Shipt®, DoorDash®, and InstaCart®.
Focus on a Sales Driven Culture, Building and Supporting Human Capital, Becoming More Relevant to Consumers, and Creating Meaningful Differentiation.

elements.title: WEIS MARKETS, INC. - Item 1. Business: Store Operations and Capital Expenditure

data.value: Stores range from 8,000 to 71,000 square feet, with an average of approximately 49,000 square feet.

Over 55,000 sq ft: 64 stores (32%); 45,000 to 54,999 sq ft: 70 stores (36%); 35,000 to 44,999 sq ft: 46 stores (23%); 25,000 to 34,999 sq ft: 12 stores (6%); Under 25,000 sq ft: 5 stores (3%); Total: 197 stores.

data.key: Store Count and Square Footage Trends
data.value: Over five periods, beginning store count ranged from 196 to 205 and ending count from 196 to 202; total square footage ranged between approximately 9,568,000 and 9,800,000 sq ft. Additions/major remodels averaged about 12 per period.

Approximately one third of the capital expenditure budget is dedicated to new/relocated stores (openings), 15-20% to store remodels, with the remainder for supply chain, technology, in-store projects, maintenance, and support functions.

Approximately 63% of products are self-distributed from its strategically located distribution center and transportation fleet; the company also operates three manufacturing facilities processing milk, ice cream, and fresh meat products.

A Pennsylvania-based retail food company primarily engaged in the sale of groceries, dairy products, frozen foods, meats, seafood, fresh produce and more. The company’s stock trades under the symbol 'WMK' on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Weis family owns approximately 65% of the outstanding shares.
Jonathan H. Weis serves as Chairman of the Board of Directors, President and Chief Executive Officer.

elements.title: Market for Registrant’s Common Equity - Comparative Shareholder Return Analysis

data.value: Item 5. Market for Registrant’s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities (continued)

The document provides a comparative analysis of the cumulative total shareholder return for Weis Markets, Inc. versus the S&P 500 and a Peer Group of similar retail grocers over a five- to six-year period. It uses line graphs and tables to depict these performance trends with an index base of 100.

Two separate chart representations titled 'Performance Comparison 2017-2022' are included. They show yearly index values for Weis Markets, S&P 500, and Peer Group, with details such as axis labels, series names, and base investment of $100 reinvesting dividends.

A table compares performance over six periods (2017 to final period) indicating that Weis Markets, Inc. outperformed both the S&P 500 and its Peer Group, reaching an index value of 224.84 versus 143.61 for the S&P 500 and 162.57 for the Peer Group.
Weis Markets, Inc., S&P 500, Peer Group (including Ingles Markets, Inc.; Village Super Market, Inc.; Smart & Final Stores, Inc.; Sprouts Farmers Market, Inc.; and The Kroger Company)
Cumulative total return with dividends reinvested, indexed values (base 100) over the period 2017-2022

elements.title: Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations: Overview

data.value: WEIS MARKETS, INC.
Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (MD&A)
To help the reader understand the company’s operations, financial condition, and business environment.

Weis Markets is a conventional supermarket chain operating 197 retail stores with approximately 23,000 associates in Pennsylvania and six surrounding states (Delaware, Maryland, New Jersey, New York, Virginia, and West Virginia).

Groceries, dairy products, frozen foods, meats, seafood, fresh produce, floral, pharmacy services, deli products, prepared foods, bakery products, beer and wine, fuel, and general merchandise such as health and beauty care and household products.
Competitive pricing strategies including Everyday Lower Price, Low Price Guarantee, Low, Low Price, 3 Day Sale, senior and military discounts, and Loyalty programs.
Approximately 63% of products are self-distributed using its own distribution center and transportation fleet; the remainder comes from direct store vendors and regional wholesalers.
Operates three facilities for processing milk, ice cream, and fresh meat products.
Sunbury, Pennsylvania (founded in 1912)
Government mandated shutdowns and emergency legislative acts in early 2020 resulted in increased sales and gross profits compared to pre-pandemic periods.

elements.title: Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations

data.value: The Company will elevate organizational capacity to support decision effectiveness and consistent execution, including aligning business functions and processes for scalability.

Continued investments in IT systems aim to improve associate engagement, increase productivity, and provide insights into customer behavior/shopping trends, supporting strategic decision measurement and financial returns.

The Company emphasizes sustainability with four key pillars—green design, natural resource conservation, food and agricultural impact, and social responsibility—with a goal to reduce its overall carbon footprint.

Management provides a Two-Year Stacked Comparable Store Sales analysis (both individual year and two-year stacked) to illustrate operating results trends, including adjustments for an additional week in 2022 and comparisons excluding fuel.

The table shows that overall comparable store sales grew 10.9% in 2022 vs 2021 (versus 1.7% for 2021 vs 2020), with similar trends observed when excluding fuel and after adjusting for the additional week in 2022. Two-year stacked metrics indicate cumulative growth, with the highest being 12.6% for overall comparable store sales.
2021 and 2020 comprised 52 weeks, while 2022 comprised 53 weeks.

elements.title: Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations – Financial Performance

data.value: For fiscal years ended December 31, 2022, December 25, 2021 and December 26, 2020, key metrics were reported. Net sales increased from 4,224,417 in 2021 to 4,695,943 in 2022 (12% increase). Gross profit margin declined from 26.8% (2020) to 25.2% (2022) with 26.4% in 2021. Operating margin fell from 4.0% in 2020 to 3.3% in 2022 (3.5% in 2021). Net income improved by 15% from 108,849 (2021) to 125,196 (2022) despite a slight fluctuation compared to 118,917 in 2020. Net income as a percent of net sales remained relatively stable at 2.7% (2022), 2.6% (2021) and 2.9% (2020).

The analysis shows net sales grew 11.2% from 2021 to 2022 compared to 2.7% from 2020 to 2021. When excluding fuel, growth was 9.6% (2022 vs. 2021) and 1.2% (2021 vs. 2020). Adjustments for an additional week in 2022 yielded 8.8% growth in net sales (2022 vs. 2021) and a striking 75% increase when excluding fuel on that adjusted basis. Comparable store sales increased 10.9% from 2021 to 2022 with a 1.7% change from 2020 to 2021, while comparable store sales excluding fuel were 9.5% (2022) versus 0.2% change. Additional context noted that 2022 comprised 53 weeks, versus 52 weeks for 2021 and 2020, and that only retail food stores are included in this calculation after meeting specific operational criteria.

elements.title: Management's Discussion and Analysis: Operating, General and Administrative Expenses

data.value: Increased sales volume; employee-related costs (wages, taxes, health care, retirement) comprise approximately 60.7% of total operating, general and administrative expenses.

Although direct store labor expenses increased in 2022 over 2021 and in 2021 over 2020, the increase in sales outpaced labor expense increases, resulting in a decline in labor as a percentage of sales (decreased by 0.5% in 2022 vs 2021 and by 0.1% in 2021 vs 2020).
Decreased by 0.2% in 2022 compared to 2021, but increased by 0.2% in 2021 compared to 2020.
2022 expense was $94.6 million (2.0% of net sales) compared to $93.8 million (2.2%) in 2021 and $90.2 million (2.2%) in 2020.
Referenced in the Liquidity and Capital Resources section; indicates an ongoing discussion on capital expenditure programs.

Table data for December 31, 2022 shows: Employee expense increased by $18,910K (-1.0% of sales), Utilities expense increased by $12,375K (0.2%), Fixed expense increased by $5,389K (-0.3%), and Other expenses increased by $21,209K (0.1%). The largest absolute change was in Other expenses, while Employee expense had the greatest percentage decrease.

Table data for December 25, 2021 shows: Employee expense increased by $5,517K (-0.2% of sales), Utilities expense increased by $3,819K (0.1%), and Fixed expense increased by $4,007K (-0.1% of sales, encompassing amortization, depreciation, insurance, and occupancy costs).

Increases in Other expenses over both periods were attributed to higher financial service fees from increased sales transactions and elevated information technology costs due to higher third-party subscriptions and consulting services.

elements.title: Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations

data.value: $5.5 million reduction in 2022, primarily due to Pennsylvania House Bill 1342 (enacted July 8, 2022) which lowers the tax rate from 9.99% in 2022 to 4.99% in 2031

Unsecured revolving credit facility under a Credit Agreement with Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. with an aggregate principal limit of $30.0 million and an additional discretionary amount of $70.0 million; matures on September 1, 2024

Comprises high-grade bonds (maturities between 1 and 20 years) and four high yield, large capitalized public company equity securities; totaled $186.4 million as of December 31, 2022

Plans to invest approximately $150 million in 2023 for new superstores, expansion and remodeling of existing units, site acquisitions, technology purchases, and upgrades to distribution facilities and transportation fleet; includes carryover projects delayed due to labor and supply chain disruptions
2004 resolution authorized repurchase of up to one million shares, with a remaining balance of 752,468 shares
Dividends per share were $1.30 in 2022, $1.25 in 2021, and $1.24 in 2020; increased quarterly dividend from 32 cents to 34 cents in Q4 2022; dividend payments subject to Board discretion

elements.title: Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates

data.value: Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (continued)

The document outlines critical accounting policies and estimates, including methods for valuing inventories (retail inventory and average cost methods, LIFO for center store and pharmacy, average cost for fresh inventories), recording allowances for inventory shortages, vendor allowances, and income tax estimations. It emphasizes the use of consistent accounting policies and the importance of management judgment, with estimates based on historical factors and periodic evaluations.

elements.title: Balance Sheet Assets and Liabilities

data.key: Current Assets - Cash and cash equivalents
Current Assets - Prepaid expenses and other current assets
Non-Current Assets - Property and equipment, net

data.value: This table presents a balance sheet comparing financial positions between December 31, 2022 and December 25, 2021 (amounts in thousands). Total assets increased from $1.91B to $1.96B, while total liabilities decreased from $690.7M to $657.3M. Shareholders' equity grew from $1.22B to $1.30B. Notable changes include an 83.6% increase in cash and cash equivalents from $86M to $158M, and a slight decrease in property and equipment. The company maintains a strong financial position with significant shareholders' equity representing about 66% of total assets.

elements.title: Comprehensive Income Statement for Fiscal Years 2020-2022

data.value: This table presents comprehensive income data for three fiscal years (2020-2022). In 2022, net income increased to 125196 with significant unrealized losses (-8135), resulting in total comprehensive income of 117061. In 2021, net income was 108849 with smaller losses (-1599) yielding 107250 comprehensive income, while 2020 uniquely showed a positive unrealized gain (1806) with net income of 118917 and comprehensive income of 120723. The trend indicates increasing net income alongside deteriorating performance in marketable securities investments.

elements.title: WEIS MARKETS, INC. REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM

data.value: In our opinion, the financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company as of December 31, 2022 and December 25, 2021.

The audit covered the consolidated balance sheets, statements of income, comprehensive income, shareholders’ equity, cash flows, and related notes for the periods ending December 31, 2022, December 25, 2021, and December 26, 2020.
The audit also addressed the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2022, with an unqualified opinion on its effectiveness provided.

Critical audit matters include the evaluation of the Company’s provision for state income taxes and the assessment of state tax positions, which involved complex judgments and increased audit efforts.
The audits were conducted in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) and the Internal Control — Integrated Framework.

elements.title: Аудиторские процедуры по оценке провизии по государственному налогу и розничного инвентаря

data.value: WEIS MARKETS, INC.
Процедуры аудита, связанные с провизией по государственному подоходному налогу и оценкой позиций по налогам, а также методикой розничного инвентаря (RIM с использованием метода LIFO)

Оценка и тестирование контроля за определением текущих и отсроченных налогов, данных и ключевых входных параметров в расчетах эффективной ставки налога, а также автоматизированных процессов и ИТ-систем, задействованных в учете инвентаря
Аудит оценок розничного инвентаря по методу RIM признан критически важным из-за его зависимости от многочисленных источников данных и необходимости привлечения опытных аудиторских и ИТ-специалистов
RSM US LLP
С 2016 года
March 1, 2023

elements.title: Business and Risk Factors

data.value: The Company’s Corporate Governance materials, including Corporate Governance Guidelines, Audit, Compensation and Disclosure Committee Charters, and Codes of Ethics, are available on the 'Governance' page of its website and by written request.

The industry is highly competitive with intense price competition, online retail growth, aggressive expansion, entry of non-traditional competitors, market consolidation, and fragmentation in retail formats, which may force the Company to reduce prices and affect sales and gross margins.
Food safety issues could lead to a loss of consumer confidence, potentially reducing customer demand and adversely impacting the Company's operations.
The loss of key senior management personnel could delay or hinder the Company’s ability to implement its business plans effectively.

Failure to execute expansion plans, including investments in stores, distribution, manufacturing projects, IT, and equipment, as well as unforeseen expenses and delays, may adversely affect the Company's results and operational benefits.

elements.title: Risk Factors

data.value: The Company’s investment portfolio—which includes corporate and municipal bonds, commercial paper, and equity securities—is exposed to changes in market interest rates, credit, liquidity, and market risks. Such risks may lead to a reduction in value or loss of liquidity, adversely affecting operations and financial results.

Unexpected factors impacting self-insurance claims, reserve estimates, inflation, litigation trends, legal interpretations, benefit adjustments and claim settlement patterns could lead to significant variability and negatively impact the Company's financial condition.

Disruptions or breaches in the Company’s complex information technology systems may result in loss of valuable proprietary and personal data, leading to operational disruptions, reputational damage, potential litigation, and financial penalties.

The Company faces risks from rising operating costs including wage increases, oil price fluctuations, union-related disruptions, and changes in vendor promotion practices, each potentially impacting margins and overall profitability.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Legal, Regulatory and Other External Risks

data.value: The Company operates in regions with varying economic, social, and climate conditions, with stores concentrated in central and northeast Pennsylvania, central Maryland, suburban Washington, DC, Baltimore, and New York’s Southern Tier.
Fluctuations in inflation, changes in population, employment, job growth, and government benefits (e.g., SNAP/EBT or child care credits) affect customer shopping habits.
Extreme annual snowfall variance in geographic regions may materially impact sales and expenses.

Subject to extensive federal, state, and local laws (health, sanitation, food labeling, equal employment opportunity, minimum wages, licensing) which might necessitate additional capital expenditures and operational adjustments.
Changes in tax laws could lead to a higher income tax rate and an increase in the Company's future effective tax rate.
The Weis family controls approximately 65% of the combined voting power of the Company's common stock, influencing director elections and major corporate decisions.

elements.title: Risk Factors (continued)

data.value: The COVID-19 pandemic caused significant volatility, uncertainty, and economic disruption affecting the Company's business, operations, and its supply chain.
Reduced workforces due to illness, quarantine, or government mandates.
Interruption in the supply chain due to the novel coronavirus.
Potential future litigation and impact from government regulations related to COVID-19.
Changes in customer procurement methods impacting demand.
Increased cyber-attacks due to remote work or work-from-home requirements.

elements.title: Item 7. MD&A: Critical Accounting Policies – Leases, Self-Insurance and Market Risk Disclosures

data.value: The Company leases approximately 49% of its open store facilities under operating leases expiring through 2036. These leases generally have fixed annual rentals with some including variable costs related to real estate taxes, insurance, and contingent rentals based on annual sales or inflation adjustments. Multiple renewal options (5 to 20 years) exist for most leases, and additional leases exist for transportation and equipment.
The Company leases or subleases space to tenants in owned, vacated, and open store facilities, with rental income recorded as part of operating, general and administrative expenses.

The Company is self-insured for most workers’ compensation, general liability, vehicle accident, and associate medical benefit claims. Liability estimates use historical data and actuarial methods for claims, including specific details about healthcare claims, stop-loss coverage, and workers’ compensation limits.

The MD&A contains forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties including economic conditions, retail industry business conditions, regulatory environment, technology, competition, and price pressures. Readers are cautioned regarding reliance on these statements.

data.key: Market Risk - Rate Sensitive Assets Table Summary
data.value: Under Item 7a, the table presents rate sensitive assets with fixed interest rate exposures and average interest rates from 2023 to 2027 and thereafter. The total fixed interest rate assets amount to $182,136,000 with a fair value of $181,234,000 as of December 31, 2022. Average interest rates range from 3.02% to 4.05%, with an overall average of 3.80%.

Not quantifiable or predictable with precision due to market volatility

elements.title: Notes 11-13: Commitments, Long-Term Debt and COVID-19 Disclosures

data.value: The Company is involved in various legal actions arising out of the normal course of business.
Contingencies are accrued when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated based on past experience.

On September 1, 2016, Weis Markets entered into a revolving credit agreement with Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., amended on September 29, 2021, maturing on September 1, 2024. It provides an unsecured revolving credit facility with an aggregate principal amount not to exceed $30.0 million plus an additional discretionary amount of $70.0 million.

As of December 31, 2022, the availability under the credit agreement was $25.5 million with $4.5 million of letters of credit outstanding, maintained primarily to support performance, payment, deposit, or surety obligations.
Interest expense related to long-term debt was $32K in 2022, $32K in 2021, and $35K in 2020.

The COVID-19 pandemic led to a national state of emergency in March 2020, with the CARES Act enacted on March 27, 2020. This resulted in incremental financial performance and increased uncertainty and risks regarding employees, customers, supply chain, and government regulation.

elements.title: WEIS MARKETS ESG and Sustainability Initiatives

data.value: The Company focuses on a four-pillared strategy: green design, natural resource conservation, food and agricultural impact, and social responsibility.
Aims to reduce overall carbon footprint by lowering greenhouse gas emissions and mitigating climate change impact.
Member of the program with eighteen stores registered, with plans to expand further.
Since 2016, 100% of the tractor fleet has been replaced with more fuel-efficient and lower-emission models.
Diverted 45 thousand tons of waste from landfills through enhanced recycling efforts.
Employs approximately 23,000 associates with a focus on talent management, development, and creating a strong employment brand.
